Returns the number of `channelRead` events seen so far in the `ChannelPipeline`.
Waits for a message part to be received and checks that it was a `.end` before returning
- deadline: The deadline by which a part must have been received.
- Throws: If the part was not a `.end` or nothing was read before the deadline.
A `VerificationError` is thrown when the verification of a `ByteToMessageDecoder` failed.
Unwrap the provided `NIOAny` that was passed to `channelRead`.

Returns the number of `close` events seen so far in the `ChannelPipeline`.

- Throws: If the part was not a `.body` or nothing was read before the deadline.
Returns the number of `userInboundEventTriggered` events seen so far in the `ChannelPipeline`.
Contains the `inputs` that were passed to the `ByteToMessageDecoder` at the point where it failed
The `errorCode` will be set to `underProduction` when a decoder didn't yield output when output was
expected. The expected output is delivered as the associated value.
The `errorCode` will be `wrongProduction` when the `expected` output didn't match the `actual`
Verifies a `ByteToMessageDecoder` by performing a number of tests.
This method is mostly useful in unit tests for `ByteToMessageDecoder`s. It feeds the inputs from
`inputOutputPairs` into the decoder in various ways and expects the decoder to produce the outputs from
The verification performs various tests, for example:
- drip feeding the bytes, one by one
- sending each complete message in one `ByteBuffer`
For `ExampleDecoder` that produces `ExampleDecoderOutput`s you would use this method the following way:
Returns the number of `channelActive` events seen so far in the `ChannelPipeline`.
Returns the number of `flush` events seen so far in the `ChannelPipeline`.
Returns the number of `triggerUserOutboundEvent` events seen so far in the `ChannelPipeline`.
Returns the number of `bind` events seen so far in the `ChannelPipeline`.
Waits for a message part to be received and checks that it was a `.head` before passing
- deadline: The deadline by which a part must have been received.
- verify: A closure which can be used to verify the contents of the `HTTPRequestHead`.
- Throws: If the part was not a `.head` or nothing was read before the deadline.
Return all event descriptions that have triggered.
This is most useful in unit tests where you want to make sure only certain events have been triggered.
- note: This API is thread-safe, you may call it from any thread. The results of this API may vary though if you
call it whilst the `Channel` this `ChannelHandler` is in is still in use.
Unwrap the provided `NIOAny` that was passed to `write`.
Returns the number of `channelReadComplete` events seen so far in the `ChannelPipeline`.
Returns the number of `errorCaught` events seen so far in the `ChannelPipeline`.
The type of the inbound data which is wrapped in `NIOAny`.
Returns the number of `channelRegistered` events seen so far in the `ChannelPipeline`.
Returns the number of `connect` events seen so far in the `ChannelPipeline`.

- Throws: If the part was not a `.head` or nothing was read before the deadline.
`errorCode` describes the concrete problem that was detected.
Returns the number of `channelInactive` events seen so far in the `ChannelPipeline`.
Returns the number of `read` events seen so far in the `ChannelPipeline`.
The type of the inbound data which will be forwarded to the next `ChannelInboundHandler` in the `ChannelPipeline`.

in the `Channel` on deconstruction. This usually means that your `ByteToMessageDecoder` did not process
Waits for a message part to be received and checks that it was a `.end` before passing
- deadline: The deadline by which a part must have been received.
- verify: A closure which can be used to verify the contents of the `HTTPHeaders?`.
- Throws: If the part was not a `.end` or nothing was read before the deadline.
The type of the outbound data which will be forwarded to the next `ChannelOutboundHandler` in the `ChannelPipeline`.
Returns the number of `channelWritabilityChanged` events seen so far in the `ChannelPipeline`.
Wrap the provided `InboundOut` that will be passed to the next `ChannelInboundHandler` by calling `ChannelHandlerContext.fireChannelRead`.
HTTP1 server that accepts and process only one request at a time.
This helps writing tests against a real server while keeping the ability to
write tests and assertions the same way we would if we were testing a
`NIOHTTP1TestServer` enables writing test cases for HTTP1 clients that have
complex behaviours like client implementing a protocol where an high level
operation translates into several, possibly parallel, HTTP requests.
- visibility on the `HTTPServerRequestPart`s received by the server;
- control over the `HTTPServerResponsePart`s send by the server.
The following code snippet shows an example test case where the client
under test sends a request to the server.
// Use your library to send a request to the server.
// Assert the server received the expected request.
// Make the server send a response to the client.
// Assert that the client received the response from the server.
Returns the number of `register` events seen so far in the `ChannelPipeline`.
Validate some basic assumptions about the number of events and if any of those assumptions are violated, throw
For example, any `Channel` should only be registered with the `Selector` at most once. That means any
`ChannelHandler` should see no more than one `register` event. If `EventCounterHandler` sees more than one
`register` event and you call `checkValidity`, it will throw `EventCounterHandler.ValidityError` with an
- note: This API is thread-safe, you may call it from any thread. The results of this API may vary though if you
call it whilst the `Channel` this `ChannelHandler` is in is still in use.
Waits for a message part to be received and checks that it was a `.body` before passing
- deadline: The deadline by which a part must have been received.
- verify: A closure which can be used to verify the contents of the `ByteBuffer`.
- Throws: If the part was not a `.body` or nothing was read before the deadline.
The type of the outbound data which is wrapped in `NIOAny`.
`EventCounterHandler` is a `ChannelHandler` that counts and forwards all the events that it sees coming through
Adding `EventCounterHandler` to any point of your `ChannelPipeline` should not change the program's behaviour.
`EventCounterHandler` is mostly useful in unit tests to validate other `ChannelHandler`'s behaviour.
- note: Contrary to most `ChannelHandler`s, all of `EventCounterHandler`'s API is thread-safe meaning that you can
query the events received from any thread.
Returns the number of `write` events seen so far in the `ChannelPipeline`.
